head.title: Memo on Rio Summit Focused on U.S. Gains

hedline.hl1: Memo on Rio Summit Focused on U.S. Gains

block.p: The distortion of the intent and content of my memorandum on the Earth Summit in Rio to Environmental Protection Agency employees is symptomatic of the problem the Bush Administration has experienced in getting fair news coverage for an environmental record that is substantive, significant and impressive (front page, Aug. 1).

The distortion of the intent and content of my memorandum on the Earth Summit in Rio to Environmental Protection Agency employees is symptomatic of the problem the Bush Administration has experienced in getting fair news coverage for an environmental record that is substantive, significant and impressive (front page, Aug. 1).

While the memorandum briefly reflects on a variety of preliminary issues leading up to the Rio conference, it focuses on significant United States accomplishments at this important international gathering:

A framework convention on climate change that commits the community of nations to a responsible course of action; a declaration on forest principles and a bold initiative by the President to double United States bilateral aid for forests; Agenda 21, the 900-page blueprint for environmental improvement in the 21st century, drawing on American experience in environmental impact assessment, toxic release inventories and public participation; and a convention on biological diversity.

The United States has stronger laws, spends more money and takes the protection of endangered wildlife more seriously than any other country on earth. That we ultimately did not sign this convention reflects serious concerns relating to financing and protection of intellectual property rights that had nothing to do with protecting biological diversity.

A fair reading of the memo makes clear that the conference was a success for the United States and for the environment. WILLIAM K. REILLY Administrator, Environmental Protection Agency Washington, Aug. 3, 1992
